div1.p: Magoon reports the number of cases of yellow fever in the Canal Zone has dramatically decreased. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Charles E. Magoon to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 6, 1905
div1.opener:
When replying refer to No:
Governor Magoon
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
EXECUTIVE OFFICE
Ancon, November 6, 1905.
My dear Major:
div1.p:
I must offer an apology for the long delay in acknowledging your
kind note of June 20th, but I have had little time for writing personal let-
ters, and I have waited, hoping that the information of the greatest interest
that I could give you - in respect to yellow fever - would continue to be of
a more favorable nature as the work progressed. I have not been disappoint-
ed in this, as the following figures will show:

Thus far this month there have been no cases of the disease re-
ported, although there is a standing reward of $50 gold, to be paid to the
first person, not connected with the Health Department, who reports a case
of yellow fever on the Isthmus. While the situation has improved as shown
by the above figures, yet there has been no let-up in the watchfulness and
work, and there will not be so long as there is the least possibility of ad-
ditional cases of the disease.

I was glad to learn, in a conversation with Mrs. Phillips a few
-2-
days ago, of your success in winning a prize for the best paper on the
treatment of diseases in the Army. Accept my congratulations.

I hope to have the pleasure of seeing you in Washington some time
during the winter. Please give my kindest regards to General O'Reilly, and
believe me.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, Charles E. Magoon Governor of the Canal Zone
then Governor of Cuba, 1906-1909.
Major J. R. Kean, U.S.A.,
Office of Surgeon General,
Washington, D.C.
